metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces  (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix（Huazhaizi desert station) from Feb to Sep, 2012
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the automatic weather station (AWS) measurements from Huazhaizi desert steppe station in the flux observation matrix from 2 June to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.31860° E, 38.76519° N) was located in a desert steppe surface, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. There are two equipment in the site, and installed by Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAREERI) and Beijing Normal University (BNU), respectively. The installation heights and orientations of BNU were as follows: two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 2.65 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04 m), and soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04 m). For the CAREERI installation: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45A; 1, 1.99 and 2.99 m, north), wind speed profile (03102; 0.48, 0.98, 1.99 and 2.99 m, north), wind direction (03302; 4 m, north), air pressure (PTB210; in waterproof box), rain gauge (CTK-15PC; 0.7 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 2.5 m, south), soil temperature profile (107; -0.04, -0.1, -0.18, -0.26, -0.34, -0.42 and -0.5 m), soil moisture profile (ML2X; -0.02, -0.1, -0.18, -0.26, -0.34, -0.42, -0.5, and -0.58 m, 3 duplicates in -0.02 m).
The observations included the following: (1)	infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm) (%). (2)	air temperature and humidity (Ta_1 m, Ta_1.99 m and Ta_2.99 m; RH_1 m, RH_1.99 m and RH_2.99 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_0.48 m, Ws_0.98 m, Ws_1.99 m and Ws_2.99 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_4 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_18 cm, Ts_26 cm, Ts_34 cm, Ts_42 cm and Ts_50 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm_1, Ms_2 cm_2, Ms_2 cm_3, Ms_10 cm, Ms_18 cm, Ms_26 cm, Ms_34 cm, Ms_42 cm, Ms_50 cm and Ms_58 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The BNU data were averaged over intervals of 10 min, The CAREERI data were averaged over intervals of 30 min. A total of 144 runs per day were recorded in BNU data and 48 records per day in CAREERI data. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2012-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of a multi-scale observation experiment in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A multi-scale observation experiment is crucial in eco-hydrological research as it addresses the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. Such experiments involve hierarchically nested scales and multidisciplinary data collection to capture detailed and varied ecological and hydrological interactions across different spatial and temporal scales.

Definition.Question: How is data quality controlled in observational datasets within eco-hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: Data quality in observational datasets within eco-hydrological studies is controlled through meticulous processes that include sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This ensures that the collected data is accurate and reliable for further scientific analysis and research.

Definition.Question: What is the role of remote sensing technology in collecting eco-hydrological data?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing technology plays a significant role in collecting eco-hydrological data by providing hyper-resolution data through instruments like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers. These technologies enable the detailed observation of environmental parameters over large and varied landscapes, contributing to a comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of measuring evapotranspiration using remote sensing in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges of measuring evapotranspiration using remote sensing in heterogeneous landscapes are primarily due to the complexity of separating soil and vegetation components, differing surface temperatures, resistances to energy exchange, and the limitations of models like the TSEB model, which require parameters and observations not readily available from operational satellite- and ground-based data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for multiscale observations in studying eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a need for multiscale observations in studying eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous surfaces because upscaling these processes is a grand challenge due to the poor availability of multiscale data. The HiWATER experiment addresses this challenge by using hierarchically nested scales to capture diverse eco-hydrological processes, thereby providing more comprehensive data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions are caused by classification errors in thermal images, uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, and inaccuracies in the estimated incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy. These factors lead to an overestimation of component temperatures and affect the TSEB model's performance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential implications of using a high-resolution thermal camera for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a high-resolution thermal camera for estimating evapotranspiration allows for more accurate separation of soil and canopy component temperatures, which leads to improved estimates of evaporation, transpiration, and overall evapotranspiration. This method can enhance validation processes through a combination of stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements, particularly in strongly advective environments.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection approaches impact the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection approaches, such as those implemented in the HiWATER experiment, provide comprehensive insights into eco-hydrological processes by capturing data across different scales and disciplines. This enables a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions through a combination of eddy covariance measurements, remote sensing, and ground-based observations, facilitating the upscaling of these processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the outcomes of implementing a rigorous data quality control process in the collection of eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a rigorous data quality control process ensures the reliability and accuracy of eco-hydrological data collected in arid regions. This involves careful sensor calibration, data collection, and processing, which allows for the generation of high-quality datasets. Such datasets are essential for accurately modeling and understanding complex hydrological and ecological interactions in these environments, as demonstrated in the HiWATER project.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of implementing a multi-scale observation experiment for evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of implementing a multi-scale observation experiment for evapotranspiration is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface, which is often hindered by poor availability of multiscale observations. This involves capturing multi-scale and multidisciplinary data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures in the estimation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures is important for better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates, especially when combined with observed ratios and measurements using stable isotopes and the eddy covariance system. This approach addresses the limitations of composite temperature separation, particularly in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective behind conducting intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations during the HiWATER project?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to investigate oasis-desert interactions and capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales. This includes using a sparse network of superstations, eddy covariance towers, and automatic meteorological stations across different landscapes, along with intensive observations at the irrigation district scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are involved in ensuring the quality control and processing of observational data collected from eco-hydrological experiments in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational data quality control involves several steps: ensuring the correct number of data entries per day, marking missing data with a specific code, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceed physical significance or instrument range, and standardizing time recording. Additionally, instruments are arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes, and observational data undergo careful quality control throughout sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multi-scale observational datasets structured and collected in the context of eco-hydrological research over heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multi-scale observational datasets are structured using a flux observation matrix, which includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This is complemented by an eco-hydrological sensor network that measures soil moisture and leaf area index. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing is conducted using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers. The data collection approach is designed to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary information from an oasis-desert area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and techniques are employed in the collection of data for evapotranspiration estimation using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in strongly advective regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TSEB model data collection involves the use of ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, high-resolution thermal cameras, and eddy covariance (EC) systems. Instruments include meteorological stations that measure parameters like air temperature, wind speed, humidity, and radiation. The approach involves partitioning ET into evaporation and transpiration using the Craig–Gordon model, and validating component temperatures with thermal infrared camera data and four-component radiometer observations.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and hierarchical arrangements enable the multi-scale observation of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions, a superstation within the oasis, and multiple eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations in surrounding landscapes.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in remote sensing contribute to the collection of high-resolution eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: In the experiment, 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer. These technologies enabled the collection of hyper-resolution data essential for observing eco-hydrological processes at multiple scales.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methods enhance the quality control and accuracy of eco-hydrological datasets obtained from field experiments?
Enablement.Answer: All observational data were carefully quality controlled through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This rigorous approach ensures the reliability and accuracy of the datasets obtained from field experiments like the HiWATER project.

Expectation.Question: Why might one anticipate challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration using models on heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: The complexity and heterogeneity of real landscapes, which contain mixed components of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistances to energy exchange, make it difficult for one-source models to accurately estimate surface evapotranspiration. Moreover, the required parameters and observations might not be readily available from operational satellite and ground-based data, limiting the applicability of models.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the data quality control measures applied in the eco-hydrological datasets collected during the HiWATER experiment?
Judgmental.Answer: The data quality control measures in the HiWATER experiment are thorough, involving the calibration of sensors, systematic data collection, processing, and dataset generation. These measures are essential for ensuring the reliability and accuracy of the multiscale eco-hydrological datasets, which include a variety of data sources like eddy covariance towers, remote sensing, and ground measurements.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in separating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions for accurate evapotranspiration estimation?
Judgmental.Answer: Separating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions is particularly challenging due to classification errors in image processing, which affect the accuracy of temperature estimates. The complexity of the landscape and variability in vegetation abundance can lead to misclassification, impacting the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates. Despite these challenges, the TSEB model has shown potential through the use of high-resolution thermal cameras and careful validation against observed data.

Judgmental.Question: How do you perceive the potential of integrating airborne remote sensing technologies with ground-based measurements for enhancing multiscale observations of eco-hydrological processes?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating airborne remote sensing technologies with ground-based measurements offers significant potential for enhancing multiscale observations. Technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers provide high-resolution data that, when combined with ground-based data, can offer comprehensive insights into eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous landscapes. This integration is crucial for addressing the challenges of scaling observations in the HiWATER experiment.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how ground-based measurements and remote sensing data are integrated for accurate surface flux estimations in heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: Ground-based measurements, such as those from eddy covariance systems and thermal cameras, are used alongside remote sensing data like LiDAR and thermal imagers to capture detailed eco-hydrological processes across different scales. The integration is achieved through models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, which uses these datasets to estimate evapotranspiration and other fluxes with the help of component temperatures and energy balance equations.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges of conducting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological experiments.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which are necessary for accurately capturing eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous surfaces. The complexity of instrumentation across hierarchically nested scales and the need for synchronization between ground-based and airborne data further complicate the data collection process.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from multiple instruments are processed and quality-controlled for these experiments.
Assertion.Answer: Data from various instruments, such as eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensors, undergo extensive quality control processes. These involve sensor calibration, data collection protocols, and data processing steps to ensure accuracy. The data are then used to generate datasets, which are made available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and describe the data collection method used to observe soil and canopy component temperatures in heterogeneous land surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: The soil and canopy component temperatures were observed using a high-resolution thermal camera as part of a series TSEB model. Ground-based measurements were applied to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using the Craig–Gordon model. Observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 CST during the daytime, which were later used to calculate the component temperatures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in the collection and processing of multiscale observations in oasis-desert areas and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the poor availability of multiscale observations, image classification errors, and uncertainties in temperature estimations due to atmospheric factors. Solutions may involve improving image classification techniques, enhancing sensor calibration, and using advanced models like the TSEB model to accurately separate soil and vegetation component temperatures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss potential datasets that could be used to investigate eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include multiscale data obtained from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) project. This includes datasets from a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor network, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, and ground measurements of vegetation dynamics. These datasets are carefully controlled for quality and are available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.
